markdown.markdown:
```{=html} ``` **ECO 230**\ **Section 005** ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## [Instructor & Contact]{.sr-only} **Mike Boland, MBA**\ **mboland\@uwlax.edu**\ **Phone:** 608-385-6497 ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## [What is Statistics?]{.sr-only} **What is statistics?** ![](media/images/w01_s03_image.jpeg){fig-alt="Photo of several dogs lying on a blanket; playful opener for the topic." width="70%"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## [Analytics Definition]{.sr-only} **Analytics is the art of finding out what is in your data.** ![](media/images/decorative-blanket.jpg){fig-alt="" aria-hidden="true" width="65%"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## [Analytics vs. Certainty]{.sr-only} **If you can (with some effort) find the answer with certainty you are using analytics.** ![](media/images/decorative-blanket-2.jpg){fig-alt="" aria-hidden="true" width="65%"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## [Analytics vs. Statistics (1)]{.sr-only} **Analytics deals with what you know.**\ **Statistics deals with what you do not know.** ![](media/images/decorative-blanket-3.jpg){fig-alt="" aria-hidden="true" width="65%"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## [Analytics vs. Statistics (2)]{.sr-only} **Analytics helps you get good questions.**\ **Statistics helps you get good answers.** ![](media/images/decorative-blanket-4.jpg){fig-alt="" aria-hidden="true" width="65%"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## [Statistics as Decision-Making]{.sr-only} **Statistics is the science of making decisions under uncertainty.** ![](media/images/decorative-blanket-5.jpg){fig-alt="" aria-hidden="true" width="65%"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## [Learning Curve]{.sr-only} ![](media/images/learning-curve.png){fig-alt="Stylized learning curve chart with Time on the x-axis and Skill on the y-axis, labeled phases ‘This Sucks’, ‘This $ucks’, and ‘This Is Fun’." width="75%"} **Learning Curve** ```{r} # install.packages(c("ggplot2", "dplyr")) # if needed library(ggplot2) library(dplyr) set.seed(42) # Helper: light moving-average to get gentle wiggles (base R, no extra packages) ma <- function(x, k = 7) { stats::filter(x, rep(1/k, k), sides = 2) |> as.numeric() } # X axis n <- 600 x <- seq(0, 100, length.out = n) # "Time" # --- Curves (all scaled to [0, 1]) ---------------------------------------- # 1) Orange: fast start, then plateaus # Use a Gompertz-like rise to a plateau; add tiny noise + smooth a_or <- 0.015 # rate y_or0 <- exp(-exp(-a_or*(x - 25))) # Gompertz shape y_or <- (y_or0 - min(y_or0)) / (max(y_or0) - min(y_or0)) y_or <- pmin(1, pmax(0, y_or + rnorm(n, 0, 0.004))) y_or <- ma(y_or, 9) y_or <- pmin(1, pmax(0, y_or)) # 2) Blue: centered S-curve (logistic), steeper in the middle k_bl <- 0.22 # steepness x0_bl <- 55 # inflection near the middle y_bl0 <- 1 / (1 + exp(-k_bl*(x - x0_bl))) y_bl <- (y_bl0 - min(y_bl0)) / (max(y_bl0) - min(y_bl0)) y_bl <- pmin(1, pmax(0, y_bl + rnorm(n, 0, 0.004))) y_bl <- ma(y_bl, 7) y_bl <- pmin(1, pmax(0, y_bl)) # 3) Purple: slow, steady climb across most of the range # Use a power curve + linear blend to stay gradual for longer y_pr0 <- (x/100)^4.35 * 0.92 + (x/100) * 0.08 y_pr <- pmin(1, pmax(0, y_pr0 + rnorm(n, 0, 0.004))) y_pr <- ma(y_pr, 9) y_pr <- pmin(1, pmax(0, y_pr)) # Bind to tidy frame df <- bind_rows( data.frame(x = x, y = y_bl, curve = "Blue – S curve"), data.frame(x = x, y = y_or, curve = "Orange – fast then plateau"), data.frame(x = x, y = y_pr, curve = "Purple – steady long climb") ) # Colors chosen to resemble your figure cols <- c( "Blue – S curve" = "#2B5C88", "Orange – fast then plateau" = "#E5871B", "Purple – steady long climb" = "#6B5CA5" ) p <- ggplot(df, aes(x, y, color = curve)) + geom_line(linewidth = 1.0, lineend = "round") + scale_color_manual(values = cols, guide = "none") + coord_cartesian(ylim = c(0, 1), xlim = c(0, 100), expand = FALSE) + scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::label_number(accuracy = 0.01)) + labs( title = "Learning Curve", x = "Time", y = "Skill" ) + theme_minimal(base_size = 16) + theme( plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 26, hjust = 0), panel.grid.minor = element_blank(), axis.title.x = element_text(margin = margin(t = 10)), axis.title.y = element_text(margin = margin(r = 10)), axis.line = element_line(color = "#333333", linewidth = 0.7), axis.ticks = element_line(color = "#333333", linewidth = 0.5) ) # Optional: label line ends like in many learning-curve graphics endpoints <- df %>% group_by(curve) %>% slice_tail(n = 1) p + geom_text( data = endpoints, aes(label = sub(".*–\\s", "", curve)), hjust = -0.05, vjust = 0.5, size = 5, fontface = "plain", show.legend = FALSE ) + coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 102)) # add room for end labels # ggsave("learning_curves.png", width = 12, height = 6, dpi = 300) ``` ::: center step1_blue.png step2_blue_orange.png step3_all.png ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## [I’m Old (humor)]{.sr-only} ![](media/images/im-old.png){fig-alt="Lightweight humorous image labeled ‘I’m Old’." width="60%"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## [ETL Overview]{.sr-only} **Extract – Transform – Load** - **Extract:** get data from its source to your working environment\ - **Transform:** clean, standardize, reshape to a consistent structure\ - **Load:** place the prepared data into the analysis tool (Excel, R, Tableau, DB) ![](media/images/etl-icons.png){fig-alt="Icon trio depicting Extract, Transform, and Load steps." width="70%"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## [Transform Emphasis]{.sr-only} **Extract – *Transform* – Load**\ Edit data so it is stored in a **consistent** and **efficient** way. ![](media/images/transform-focus.png){fig-alt="Diagram emphasizing the Transform phase: cleaning, reshaping, standardizing fields like dates, categories, and locations." width="70%"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## [Load Destinations]{.sr-only} **Extract – Transform – *Load*** **Destinations:** Databases, Excel, R, Tableau, SPSS ![](media/images/load-destinations.png){fig-alt="Row of logos/icons for common analysis tools: database cylinder, Excel, R, Tableau, SPSS." width="80%"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## [Video: ETL (watch on Canvas) + Transcript]{.sr-only} > **Watch on Canvas:** *ETL overview video*\ > (Replace `#` with your Canvas URL.) [▶️ Open video in Canvas](#)
Transcript — ETL (click to expand) {{< include transcripts/video1.md >}}
------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## [Unit of Analysis]{.sr-only} **Unit of Analysis**\ What does each **row / observation / grain** in this dataset represent? - Everyone in a ZIP code\ - Individual consumers\ - Individual purchases\ - GDP of an economy\ - Population of a planet ![](media/images/unit-of-analysis.png){fig-alt="Visual cue reminding that each dataset row should map to a clearly defined observational unit." width="70%"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## [Data Grouping: Cross-Sectional]{.sr-only} **Data Grouping: Cross‑Sectional**\ A snapshot of different subjects at **one point in time**. ![](media/images/cross-sectional.png){fig-alt="Photo of a water droplet frozen in time; metaphor for a single-time snapshot of data." width="70%"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## [Data Grouping: Time-Series]{.sr-only} **Data Grouping: Time‑Series**\ Track measurements of (often different) subjects **over time**. ![](media/images/time-series.png){fig-alt="Illustration of growth over months; metaphor for changes tracked over time." width="70%"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## [Data Grouping: Panel]{.sr-only} **Data Grouping: Panel**\ Track the **same subjects** repeatedly over time. ![](media/images/panel-data.png){fig-alt="Illustration of multiple parallel timelines for the same subjects; metaphor for panel data." width="70%"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## [Tall vs Wide; Know Your Structure]{.sr-only} **Understand the Structure of your data** - **Tall** — more rows, fewer columns\ - **Wide** — more columns, fewer rows **Example (Tall):** | Name | Variable | Value | |------|----------|-------| | Mike | Gender | Male | | Mike | Age | 43 | | Mike | Monday | 6.5 | | Mike | Tuesday | 7.2 | **Example (Wide):** | Name | Gender | Age | Monday | Tuesday | |------|--------|-----|--------|---------| | Mike | Male | 43 | 6.5 | 7.2 | ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## [Rows vs Columns]{.sr-only} **Rows** stack **observations**.\ **Columns** hold **variables**. ![](media/images/rows-columns.png){fig-alt="Simple grid with arrows: rows for observations (left-to-right), columns for variables (top-to-bottom)." width="70%"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## [Data Types Overview]{.sr-only} **Categories** • **Numbers**\ **Continuous** • **Discrete**\ **Categorical** (**logical/true–false**, **ordinal**, **factor**)\ **Numeric** (**integer**, **double/real**) ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## [Observations — Atomic Data Example]{.sr-only} **Observations (Atomic Data)** — sleep tracking example - Start Time: 10:53 PM\ - End Time: 6:18 AM\ - REM: 87 minutes; Deep: 231; Light: 127\ - Total Sleep: 445; Quality: 92%\ - Name: Mike; Date: 9/7/2023; Gender: Male; Location: Bed ![](media/images/atomic-data.png){fig-alt="Cube metaphor for an atomic observation; each row represents one measured event with associated variables." width="60%"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## [Dimensions & Measures]{.sr-only} **Dimensions** *(categories, filters, axis labels)*: Month, Location, Person\ **Measures** *(aggregations)*: Averages, Standard Deviations, Counts, Sums **Example (June, Glamping):**\ Mean = 523.12 minutes · Median = 600 minutes · Quality = 82.35% · N = 2,345 ![](media/images/dimensions-measures.png){fig-alt="Schematic showing dimensions (Month, Location, Person) and measures (Average, STD, Count)." width="70%"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## [Example Table]{.sr-only} **Measures vs. Dimensions; Tall vs. Wide** \``{.markdown} Name,Gender,Location,Month,Day,Start,End,REM,Deep,Light,Total Cam,M,Glamping,Jan,Mon,10:17 PM,8:21 AM,10,80,28,118 Cam,M,Home,Jul,Mon,8:20 PM,9:32 AM,100,179,234,513 John,M,Home,Aug,Mon,8:32 PM,11:32 AM,86,359,233,677 Lydia,F,Home,Aug,Mon,8:34 AM,4:45 AM,98,299,219,616`

**Learning Curve** ```{r} # install.packages(c("ggplot2", "dplyr")) # if needed library(ggplot2) library(dplyr) set.seed(42) # Helper: light moving-average to get gentle wiggles (base R, no extra packages) ma <- function(x, k = 7) { stats::filter(x, rep(1/k, k), sides = 2) |> as.numeric() } # X axis n <- 600 x <- seq(0, 100, length.out = n) # "Time" # --- Curves (all scaled to [0, 1]) ---------------------------------------- # 1) Orange: fast start, then plateaus # Use a Gompertz-like rise to a plateau; add tiny noise + smooth a_or <- 0.015 # rate y_or0 <- exp(-exp(-a_or*(x - 25))) # Gompertz shape y_or <- (y_or0 - min(y_or0)) / (max(y_or0) - min(y_or0)) y_or <- pmin(1, pmax(0, y_or + rnorm(n, 0, 0.004))) y_or <- ma(y_or, 9) y_or <- pmin(1, pmax(0, y_or)) # 2) Blue: centered S-curve (logistic), steeper in the middle k_bl <- 0.22 # steepness x0_bl <- 55 # inflection near the middle y_bl0 <- 1 / (1 + exp(-k_bl*(x - x0_bl))) y_bl <- (y_bl0 - min(y_bl0)) / (max(y_bl0) - min(y_bl0)) y_bl <- pmin(1, pmax(0, y_bl + rnorm(n, 0, 0.004))) y_bl <- ma(y_bl, 7) y_bl <- pmin(1, pmax(0, y_bl)) # 3) Purple: slow, steady climb across most of the range # Use a power curve + linear blend to stay gradual for longer y_pr0 <- (x/100)^4.35 * 0.92 + (x/100) * 0.08 y_pr <- pmin(1, pmax(0, y_pr0 + rnorm(n, 0, 0.004))) y_pr <- ma(y_pr, 9) y_pr <- pmin(1, pmax(0, y_pr)) # Bind to tidy frame df <- bind_rows( data.frame(x = x, y = y_bl, curve = "Blue – S curve"), data.frame(x = x, y = y_or, curve = "Orange – fast then plateau"), data.frame(x = x, y = y_pr, curve = "Purple – steady long climb") ) # Colors chosen to resemble your figure cols <- c( "Blue – S curve" = "#2B5C88", "Orange – fast then plateau" = "#E5871B", "Purple – steady long climb" = "#6B5CA5" ) p <- ggplot(df, aes(x, y, color = curve)) + geom_line(linewidth = 1.0, lineend = "round") + scale_color_manual(values = cols, guide = "none") + coord_cartesian(ylim = c(0, 1), xlim = c(0, 100), expand = FALSE) + scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::label_number(accuracy = 0.01)) + labs( title = "Learning Curve", x = "Time", y = "Skill" ) + theme_minimal(base_size = 16) + theme( plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 26, hjust = 0), panel.grid.minor = element_blank(), axis.title.x = element_text(margin = margin(t = 10)), axis.title.y = element_text(margin = margin(r = 10)), axis.line = element_line(color = "#333333", linewidth = 0.7), axis.ticks = element_line(color = "#333333", linewidth = 0.5) ) # Optional: label line ends like in many learning-curve graphics endpoints <- df %>% group_by(curve) %>% slice_tail(n = 1) p + geom_text( data = endpoints, aes(label = sub(".*–\\s", "", curve)), hjust = -0.05, vjust = 0.5, size = 5, fontface = "plain", show.legend = FALSE ) + coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 102)) # add room for end labels # ggsave("learning_curves.png", width = 12, height = 6, dpi = 300) ``` ::: center step1_blue.png step2_blue_orange.png step3_all.png :::
